title: Should the sets of library and language features be disjoint?

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: T-infra
labels.description: Relevant to the infrastructure team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Currently, there [is a check](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/c6afde6c46d167c9c75389b887f1d2498aeef3e4/src/tools/tidy/src/features.rs#L248-L250) in tidy that ensures that there is no library feature and language feature of the same name. Its presence [is also mentioned](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/c6afde6c46d167c9c75389b887f1d2498aeef3e4/src/tools/tidy/src/features.rs#L16) in the documentation above.

This check [was present](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/21248/commits/11f4d62a062a5c80fad414c457e2a7dbc9a1d6cc#diff-eb84472009c2f21296e20169c0691318R119) since #21248, and has caused multiple additions that have both library and language components to be split up:

* `i128` / `i128_type`
* `inclusive_range` / `inclusive_range_syntax`
* `profiler_runtime` / `profiler_runtime_lib`

PR #40939 has challenged the status quo, by reusing the lang feature `proc_macro` inside libraries provided to programs. It actually [added an exception](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/commit/e42836b2085233323339bacb636ecf9c28e8422e#diff-e7f0adcf2688b6a55b1f70d117ed7e17L248) to the tidy check in order to get it passing.

There has been [discussion](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/40939#issuecomment-296422560) about this in the thread of #40939 and the resolution was to allow `proc_macro` to share the feature gate.

So my question is: which purpose does this check serve? should the check be present, or should it be abolished? Should the `proc_macro` feature gate be split up into a library component and a lang component?
